I just began to plan a USA road trip with a friend of mine. We are from Europe and while it's not our first time in the States it's surely our first attempt at the fabled kind of trip made famous by Kerouac.

The image above is just the result of a google search to show our starting and final points, we haven't decide on the precise route.
That's why I'm here looking for advices from the few people that will take the time to answer (PMS are ok as well) on the topics of: locations, equipment, car choice and in general on what should I do to fully enjoy an american road trip :)

This will happen starting the 3rd of August, lasting for about 2 weeks. I guess the heat will be an issue...

Hi there. My name is Brook. I am a 3 year old, spayed, female. I am a very particular cat, and I like my attention on my terms. I can not live with children under the age of 14, and im not sure how I feel about other animals. Im not your real affection girl, but thats not to say I wont warm up to you once I get settled into my new home. I am looking for a family with patience, and people who dont expect me to all lovey dovey all the time. If your looking for an independent , young girl, then come meet me today!

Site	Humane Society of Harford County 
Source: http://www.harfordshelter.org/animals/cats/

A tabby with a touch of Siamese, particularly in my personality, I'm a sassy gal on a wet food only diet (I will bring plenty), my habits are all ideal except for I'm mouthy! No, not in a vocal way but in a inappropriate use of my teeth - ie I get overstimulated, overzealous, overexcited. So I need an alpha owner who is very experienced and knows how to manage this type of behavior. I don't really like other cats BUT that having been said would grow to be able to play with a rough and tumble boy, ideally younger than me, if someone could do a long slow integration. I am a bit overly greedy for food so you have to watch my intake, and I have my destress pill mixed into my food every day. Litterbox is perfect. I can be an active and energetic player. If you're looking for someone full of p*ss and vinegar, maybe I'm your gal! Beware though I'm not going to match with any cat who is soft in mind or body!

ID Number:	VA12113
Source: https://va.siameserescue.org/VAadopt.php

Maya is a great dog that loves attention from all humans and is friendly with everyone she meets. She is a smarty pants who knows her basic commands and learns new tricks quickly, especially if treats are involved! Maya can be super active when her family wants to go for a walk or run and can also be a big cuddler when it is time to relax…the best of both worlds! She is very athletic and would likely do amazing learning agility. Maya is looking for an active family to help her burn off her energy through running, playing fetch, or chasing a toy. She would do best in a home with a fenced in yard where she would not need too many walks around the neighborhood. While Maya LOVES people and always wants to cover them in kisses, she is not such a fan of other dogs and would prefer to be the only pet in her home. When she is super happy, Maya has even been known to crack a smile!”

(7C Kennel)

Maya videos:
https://youtu.be/00Ssusebiuw
Maya pictures:
https://youtu.be/uGl32Ae14MQ
Check her progress here:  https://m.facebook.com/Snehassfosters

Source: https://lostdogrescue.org/dog/maya-the-heeler/?status=for-adoption

data.title: U.S. Secretary of War Edwin M. Stanton (USA)

images.description:
U.S. Secretary of War under President Abraham Lincoln during the American Civil War.

#colorized #photoshop #history #america

colorized U.S. Secretary of War Edwin McMasters Stanton (USA)

Edwin McMasters Stanton was born in Steubenville, Ohio, on 19 December 1814.  He studied law and was admitted to practice in 1835.  Stanton worked hard at the expense of his health.  In 1837, he was elected the prosecutor of Harrison County.  He married his first wife, but she died in late 1841.  Stanton’s grief “verged on insanity”.

Stanton continued to expand his law practice in Virginia and Pennsylvania.  He took on higher profile cases and continued to gain prominence as an attorney.  He married Ellen Hutchinson, 16 years his junior, in 1856 and leased a home in Washington, D.C.  He became acquainted with Jeremiah S. Black, the chief judge of Pennsylvania’s Supreme Court.  This friendship bore fruit when Black was appointed Attorney General under President James Buchanan.  Stanton was selected to defend the administration’s interests in California and spent the next two years on the other side of the country.

In 1859, Stanton defended New York representative Daniel Sickles for the murder of Sickles’ wife’s lover, Philip Barton Key, the U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia and the son of Francis Scott Key.  The scandal drew national attention.  Stanton argued that marriage is sacred and that a man should have the right to defend his marriage against those who chose to defile the purity of the sacrament.  Sickles was found not guilty and went to serve as a general in the Union Army during the Civil War.

In late 1860, Stanton assisted Black in providing Buchanan with insight into the legality and constitutionality of secession agreeing with Black that secession was in fact illegal.  Buchanan’s cabinet was disgruntled with his weak handling of secession.  On 5 December, Secretary of the Treasury Howell Cobb resigned.  On 9 December, Secretary of State Lewis Cass resigned.  Black was nominated to replace Cass and Stanton was confirmed as Buchanan’s new Attorney General.

Stanton found the cabinet in disarray over secession.  Buchanan assured the South that military installations would not be reinforced unless force was use against them, however, on the day Stanton assumed his post, Maj. Robert Anderson moved his unit to Fort Sumter, South Carolina, angering Southerners.  South Carolina demanded federal forces be withdrawn.  Stanton, Black, and Postmaster General Joseph Holt thought Buchanan’s response too placatory and offered their resignations.

Stanton served as President Abraham Lincoln’s Secretary of War Simon Cameron’s advisor.  Cameron’s department was riddled with corruption.  The end came when Cameron and Stanton tried to insert a call to arm slaves in Cameron’s report to Congress.  Lincoln had the call removed, but the press received the call and Lincoln was excoriated by Republicans who thought him weak on the issue of slavery.  Lincoln resolved to dismiss Cameron, but Cameron would not resign until he was sure of his successor and leave without damaging his reputation.

Cameron filled a vacancy as Minister to Russia.  Lincoln thought Holt best for the War post, but Secretary of State William H. Seward and Secretary of the Treasury Salmon Chase, Stanton’s friend, preferred Edwin Stanton.  On 20 January, Stanton took control of the War Department.  Stanton ended the spoils system of military promotions, developed better relations with Congress, and ordered that all military contracts be filled within the country.  He worked to create an effective transportation and communication network across the North focusing on railroads and telegraph lines.  Under Stanton, the War Department consolidated responsibility for internal security.

On 11 March, Lincoln, tired of General-in-Chief George McClellan’s inaction, replaced him with Stanton.  Stanton eventually gave in to McClellan’s calls for reinforcements during the Peninsula Campaign sending Maj. Gen. William B. Franklin’s division.  On 3 April, Stanton suspended military recruiting efforts under the mistaken impression that McClellan’s campaign would end the war.  When McClellan was repulsed by Robert E. Lee, Stanton was forced to restored recruiting operations on 6 July.  Lincoln soon realized that he and Stanton needed a skilled commander to serve as general-in-chief and on 23 July, Maj. Gen. Henry W. Halleck was confirmed as the new general-in-chief of Union forces.

Following the Battle of Fredericksburg, Maj. Gen. Ambrose Burnside was replaced by Maj. Gen. Joseph Hooker in command of the Army of the Potomac.  Stanton preferred Maj. Gen. William Rosecrans, but Lincoln disregarded his opinion.  Hooker was defeated at Chancellorsville in May 1863.  Stanton found the army had become grossly undisciplined, and he petitioned for liquor and women to be forbidden in Hooker’s ranks.  When Hooker finally resigned, Stanton and Lincoln decided Maj. Gen. George Meade would lead the army.

On 4 July 1863, new arrived of Union victories at Gettysburg and Vicksburg.  The good mood soon soured when Meade refused to vigorously pursue Lee.  Then in late September, Rosecrans was defeated at Chickamauga and trapped in Chattanooga, Tennessee.  Stanton organized the secret transport of thousands of Union troops west by rail.  Lincoln and Stanton agreed to make Maj. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant command of Union forces in the west, while replacing Rosecrans with Maj. Gen. George H. Thomas in command of the Army of the Cumberland.  Grant was able to break out of Chattanooga in late 1863.

Grant was promoted to lieutenant general and took the fight to Lee in Virginia.  Lincoln and his new Vice President Andrew Johnson won the 1864 Presidential Election.  Several days before the election, Stanton ordered soldiers from key states such as Illinois to be returned home to vote.  He also used his War Department powers to ensure that Republican voters were not harassed or threatened at the polls.

On 9 April 1865, Lee surrendered, and the war was effectively over.  On 13 April, Stanton suspended conscription and recruiting.  Lincoln invited Stanton, Grant and their wives to join him at Ford’s Theatre the next evening.  Stanton routinely rejected Lincoln’s invitations to the theatre and neither Stanton’s nor Grant’s wives would go unless the other went.  Lincoln eventually went with Maj. Henry Rathbone and his fiancée.  Stanton visited a bedridden Seward and then went to bed that Friday evening.  He was awoken by his wife yelling that Seward had been murdered and Lincoln might also be dead.  Stanton refused pleas not to go out and immediately went to Seward.  He ordered the homes of all members of the cabinet and the Vice President be put under guard.

Stanton and Secretary of the Navy Gideon Welles rushed to Ford’s Theatre and witnessed Lincoln’s death.  Andrew Johnson was sworn in as President in the morning.  However, Stanton “was indeed in virtual control of the government.  He had charge of the Army, Johnson was barely sworn in and vastly unsure of himself, and Congress was not in session.”  Stanton vigorously oversaw the arrest and convictions of the conspirators.

In late April, Maj. Gen. William T. Sherman negotiated peace with his Confederate adversary General Joseph Johnston in North Carolina.  Sherman’s truce was condemned by the administration and Stanton virtually accused Sherman of disloyalty in the press.  When Sherman read Stanton’s statements, he and his wife’s powerful family, the Ewings, wanted Stanton to rescind his remarks publicly.  Stanton refused.  At the Grand Review of the Armies, Sherman saluted the President and Grant, but slighted the secretary of war by walking past without a handshake.
Stanton was now tasked with reshaping the military into a capable peacetime force.  Stanton proposed military occupation for the South, but President Johnson argued for the more lenient measures proposed by Lincoln.  The Radical Republican disagreed and supported Stanton.  Following the 1866 mid-term elections, Republicans had a two-thirds majority in Congress and sought to remove Johnson.  They presented the Tenure of Office Bill, written with Stanton in mind.  The President had long considered replacing Stanton with Sherman; the Tenure of Office Bill would have made this illegal without the advice and consent of Congress.  Johnson vetoed the bill; Congress overrode the veto the same day.

Now protected by the new law, Stanton’s opposed Johnson more openly.  Johnson informed Grant that he would remove Stanton and make Grant Secretary of War.  Grant and Seward opposed the idea, but Welles and Chase, now Chief Justice of the Supreme Court and no longer friends with Stanton, supported Johnson’s plan.  On 12 August 1867, Johnson suspended Stanton from his position and notified the Senate pursuant to the Tenure of Office Act.

On 13 January 1868, the Senate voted to reinstate Stanton as War Secretary.  Grant immediately turned the office back over to Stanton.  Johnson tried to diminish the power of Stanton’s office, regularly disregarding it.  On 21 February, Johnson again fired Stanton.  On 24 February, the House of Representatives impeached Johnson.  Stanton remained barred up in the War Department, occasionally sneaking off to visit his home.  Despite a predominately Republican Senate, Johnson was acquitted and Stanton submitted his resignation.

Stanton’s health had deteriorated due to his hard work during the war and his personal finances were in shambles.  He rejected calls to run for Senate, choosing instead to resume his law practice.  He campaigned for Robert C. Schenck and other Ohio Republicans and Grant.  His physician warned him against making lengthy speeches as his asthmas irritated him severely.

His health continued to fail in 1869.  Many speculated that President Grant, who had largely ignored Stanton for months, was due to reward him for his campaigning efforts.  Stanton stated that he would reject any position in the administration due to his failing health.  However, his health improved with in Spring.  Grant offered Stanton the U.S. diplomatic mission to Mexico.  Stanton declined.

Later in the year, Stanton decided to lobby Grant for a position on the United States Supreme Court.  He was nominated on his 55th birthday and confirmed shortly thereafter.  On the night of 23 December, Stanton complained of pains in his head, neck, and spine.  His breathing became difficult and his heart and lungs felt constricted.  His condition improved around midnight but he soon lost consciousness.  At about 3 am, Surgeon General Joseph Barnes check his pulse and breathing but felt nothing.  Edwin Stanton died on 24 December 1869.
